articles.headline: 2-Minute Showers and a Flotilla of Gas Shipments: Europe Braces for Winter
articles.snippet: Countries across the continent have taken extraordinary steps to decrease energy use and ramp up supply, moving swiftly away from their longtime primary provider, Russia.
articles.abstract: Countries across the continent have taken extraordinary steps to decrease energy use and ramp up supply, moving swiftly away from their longtime primary provider, Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: A flotilla of tankers carrying liquefied natural gas have been parked in a maritime traffic jam off the coast of Spain in recent days, waiting to unload their precious cargo for Europe’s power grid. In Finland, where sweltering sauna baths are a national pastime, the government is urging friends and families to take saunas together to save energy.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Patricia Cohen

articles.headline: Food Prices Soar, and So Do Companies’ Profits
articles.snippet: Some companies and restaurants have continued to raise prices on consumers even after their own inflation-related costs have been covered.
articles.abstract: Some companies and restaurants have continued to raise prices on consumers even after their own inflation-related costs have been covered.

articles.byline: By Isabella Simonetti and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Truth Social’s Influence Grows Despite Its Business Problems
articles.snippet: The right-wing social network faces two federal investigations and an uncertain financial future. But it has still managed to outpace its rivals.
articles.abstract: The right-wing social network faces two federal investigations and an uncertain financial future. But it has still managed to outpace its rivals.

articles.headline: The Pandemic Generation Goes to College. It Has Not Been Easy.
articles.snippet: Students missed a lot of high school instruction. Now many are behind, especially in math, and getting that degree could be harder.
articles.abstract: Students missed a lot of high school instruction. Now many are behind, especially in math, and getting that degree could be harder.

articles.headline: Bolsonaro Agrees to Transition, Two Days After Losing Brazil Election
articles.snippet: Breaking his silence, President Jair Bolsonaro did not admit defeat or repeat his baseless claims about election fraud, but his administration signaled that the transfer of power would proceed.
articles.abstract: Breaking his silence, President Jair Bolsonaro did not admit defeat or repeat his baseless claims about election fraud, but his administration signaled that the transfer of power would proceed.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — Two days after losing Brazil’s presidential election, President Jair Bolsonaro agreed to a transition of power on Tuesday, easing fears that the far-right leader would contest the results after warning for months that the only way he would lose would be if the vote were stolen.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas and André Spigariol
